title: Share of described species that have been evaluated for their extinction risk

extinction_risk.title: Extinction risk
extinction_risk.content:
The International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) evaluates the risk of a species going extinct [based on several criteria](https://portals.iucn.org/library/sites/library/files/documents/RL-2001-001.pdf), including their geographical range and current population size. 

The IUCN publishes these assessments in its flagship Red List.

Species are sorted into nine categories, extending through: Not Evaluated, Data Deficient, Least Concern, Near Threatened, Vulnerable, Endangered, Critically Endangered, Extinct in the Wild and Extinct.

taxonomic_group.title: Taxonomic group
taxonomic_group.content: A taxonomic group is a category in the scientific classification of living things, based on shared characteristics and genetic similarity. It is arranged in a hierarchical system, with each group being more specific than the one above it, and all groups forming the entire classification of living things.

subtitle: In many [taxonomic groups](#dod:taxonomic_group), very few described species have been evaluated for their [extinction risk](#dod:extinction_risk) level. This means the estimated number of species at risk of extinction in these groups is likely to be a significant undercount.
